item.description: "Therefore you shall do my statutes and keep my rules and perform them, and then you will dwell in the land securely." - Leviticus 25:18
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. Is the law of retaliation contained in this passage about personal vengeance or public justice?

2. This passage contains instructions for a sabbath year in which the children of Israel were to allow the land to rest - they were not to plant or harvest. If they obeyed this instruction, how would they be provided for during that year?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: "Therefore you shall do my statutes and keep my rules and perform them, and then you will dwell in the land securely." - Leviticus 25:18

item.title: Bible Reading: Leviticus 22-23
item.description: “And you shall not profane my holy name, that I may be sanctified among the people of Israel. I am the Lord who sanctifies you.” — Leviticus 22:32
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. What type of offering did God not accept?

2. How many feasts or holy convocations are listed in this passage?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: “And you shall not profane my holy name, that I may be sanctified among the people of Israel. I am the Lord who sanctifies you.” — Leviticus 22:32

item.title: Bible Reading: Leviticus 19-21
item.description: "Consecrate yourselves, therefore, and be holy, for I am the Lord your God. Keep my statutes and do them; I am the Lord who sanctifies you." - Leviticus 20:7-8
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. What personal provisions for caring for the poor are outlined in this passage?

2. What is the equivalent of this practice/principle today?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: "Consecrate yourselves, therefore, and be holy, for I am the Lord your God. Keep my statutes and do them; I am the Lord who sanctifies you." - Leviticus 20:7-8

item.title: Bible Reading: Leviticus 17-18
item.description: "[K]eep my statutes and my rules; if a person does them, he shall live by them: I am the Lord." - Leviticus 18:5
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. Instruction is given not to consume blood, and the reasons are life is in the blood and blood is shed for a purpose. What is that purpose?

2. The children of Israel were instructed to not conduct themselves in the same way as those who occupied the land of Canaan. Is there a biblical principle in the instruction that applies to us? If so, what is it?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: "[K]eep my statutes and my rules; if a person does them, he shall live by them: I am the Lord." - Leviticus 18:5

item.title: Bible Reading: Leviticus 13-14
item.description: “The leprous person who has the disease shall wear torn clothes and let the hair of his head hang loose, and he shall cover his upper lip and cry out, ‘Unclean, unclean.’” — Leviticus 13:45
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. When a person had what appeared to be leprosy, they were declared "unclean" and isolated for some time. This isolation had both spiritual and physical implications. Why was the person isolated or quarantined?

2. Based upon isolation over the physical concerns, do we see anything similar to this today?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: “The leprous person who has the disease shall wear torn clothes and let the hair of his head hang loose, and he shall cover his upper lip and cry out, ‘Unclean, unclean.’” — Leviticus 13:45

item.title: Bible Reading: Leviticus 10-12
item.description: Then Moses said to Aaron, "This is what the Lord has said: ?'Among those who are near me I will be sanctified, and before all the people I will be glorified.?'" And Aaron held his peace." - Leviticus 10:3
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. Why were Nadab and Abihu consumed by fire from the Lord?

2. Through Moses what was the Lord's message about how people are to approach Him?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: Then Moses said to Aaron, "This is what the Lord has said: ?'Among those who are near me I will be sanctified, and before all the people I will be glorified.?'" And Aaron held his peace." - Leviticus 10:3

item.title: Bible Reading: Leviticus 7-9
item.description: "[T]he glory of the Lord appeared to all the people. And fire came out from before the Lord and consumed the burnt offering . . . , and when all the people saw it, they shouted and fell on their faces." - Leviticus 9:23b?-24
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. What was the purpose of the peace offering?

2. In this passage, how was the anointing oil used?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: "[T]he glory of the Lord appeared to all the people. And fire came out from before the Lord and consumed the burnt offering . . . , and when all the people saw it, they shouted and fell on their faces." - Leviticus 9:23b?-24

item.title: Bible Reading: Leviticus 4-6
item.description: "And the priest shall make atonement for him for the sin which he has committed, and he shall be forgiven." - Leviticus 4:35b
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. What type of offering was a person to bring if they unintentionally or unknowingly sinned?

2. According to this passage, lying to one's neighbor about that neighbor's property is a sin against whom?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: "And the priest shall make atonement for him for the sin which he has committed, and he shall be forgiven." - Leviticus 4:35b

item.title: Bible Reading: Leviticus 1-3
item.description: The Lord called Moses and spoke to him from the tent of meeting, saying, "Speak to the people of Israel and say to them, When any one of you brings an offering to the Lord, you shall bring your offering of livestock from the herd or from the flock." - Leviticus 1:1?-2
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. Why do you think God was so explicit in what and how offerings were to be made?

2. What are we to offer to God under the new covenant? (Hint: Rom. 12:1-2)
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: The Lord called Moses and spoke to him from the tent of meeting, saying, "Speak to the people of Israel and say to them, When any one of you brings an offering to the Lord, you shall bring your offering of livestock from the herd or from the flock." - Leviticus 1:1?-2

item.title: Bible Reading: Exodus 37-38
item.description: These are the records of the tabernacle, the tabernacle of the testimony, as they were recorded at the commandment of Moses, the responsibility of the Levites under the direction of Ithamar the son of Aaron the priest. — Exodus 38:21
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. Do you think there was a reason God provided explicit instruction on the design of the tabernacle rather than allowing Moses to design it?

2. What was the age at which the men were included in the census? Why do you think that age was chosen?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: These are the records of the tabernacle, the tabernacle of the testimony, as they were recorded at the commandment of Moses, the responsibility of the Levites under the direction of Ithamar the son of Aaron the priest. — Exodus 38:21

item.title: Bible Reading: Exodus 35-36
item.description: And they came, everyone whose heart stirred him, and everyone whose spirit moved him, and brought the Lord ‘s contribution to be used for the tent of meeting, and for all its service, and for the holy garments. — Exodus 35:21
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. Where did most of the gold, silver, and bronze come from, which the people gave to construct the tabernacle and garments for the priests?

2. What did the craftsmen, who were working on the sanctuary, tell Moses about the offering of the people? It was:

  1. Too skimpy
  2. Just right
  3. Too much
  4. None of the above
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: And they came, everyone whose heart stirred him, and everyone whose spirit moved him, and brought the Lord ‘s contribution to be used for the tent of meeting, and for all its service, and for the holy garments. — Exodus 35:21

item.title: Bible Reading: Exodus 33-34
item.description: “For I will cast out nations before you and enlarge your borders; no one shall covet your land, when you go up to appear before the Lord your God three times in the year.” — Exodus 34:24
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. Moses did not want to go into the promised land without what going with them?

2. Why do you think the Lord warned the children of Israel not to make covenants/treaties with the inhabitants of the land into which they were going?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: “For I will cast out nations before you and enlarge your borders; no one shall covet your land, when you go up to appear before the Lord your God three times in the year.” — Exodus 34:24

item.title: Bible Reading: Exodus 30-32
item.description: “And I have given to all able men ability, that they may make all that I have commanded you.” — Exodus 31:6b
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. Who ultimately appointed the artisans who designed and built the tabernacle?

2. What example did God provide as it pertained to the Sabbath?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: “And I have given to all able men ability, that they may make all that I have commanded you.” — Exodus 31:6b

item.title: Bible Reading: Exodus 29
item.description: “I will dwell among the people of Israel and will be their God. And they shall know that I am the LORD their God, who brought them out of the land of Egypt that I might dwell among them. I am the LORD their God.” — Exodus 29:45–46
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. What does it mean to consecrate or sanctify?

2. Why do you think it was important that the priests be consecrated for service in the tabernacle?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: “I will dwell among the people of Israel and will be their God. And they shall know that I am the LORD their God, who brought them out of the land of Egypt that I might dwell among them. I am the LORD their God.” — Exodus 29:45–46

item.title: Bible Reading: Exodus 28
item.description: “You shall make a plate of pure gold and engrave on it, like the engraving of a signet, ‘Holy to the Lord.’” — Exodus 28:36
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. Who was Moses instructed to select to make the garments for the priests?

2. What does this passage say about where vocational skills come from and how we are to use them?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: “You shall make a plate of pure gold and engrave on it, like the engraving of a signet, ‘Holy to the Lord.’” — Exodus 28:36

item.title: Bible Reading: Exodus 26-27
item.description: "And you shall hang the veil . . . and bring the ark of the testimony in there within the veil. And the veil shall separate for you the Holy Place from the Most Holy." - Exodus 26:33
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. What, if anything, can we understand about worshipping God based upon His instructions regarding the tabernacle?

2. What was behind the veil in the tabernacle?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: "And you shall hang the veil . . . and bring the ark of the testimony in there within the veil. And the veil shall separate for you the Holy Place from the Most Holy." - Exodus 26:33

item.title: Bible Reading: Exodus 23-25
item.description: “[Y]ou shall not bow down to their gods nor serve them, nor do as they do, but you shall utterly overthrow them and break their pillars in pieces.” — Exodus 23:24
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. To confuse the inhabitants of Canaan, what did God promise to send before the children of Israel?

2. God told Moses to collect an offering of the materials needed to build the tabernacle. What was to be the attitude of those who gave?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: “[Y]ou shall not bow down to their gods nor serve them, nor do as they do, but you shall utterly overthrow them and break their pillars in pieces.” — Exodus 23:24

item.title: Bible Reading: Exodus 20-22
item.description: “In every place where I cause my name to be remembered I will come to you and bless you.” — Exodus 20:24b
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. These passages record the elements of the Mosaic covenant, which is identified by the ____ Commandments.

2. Which commandment is associated with a warning of its impact upon subsequent generations?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: “In every place where I cause my name to be remembered I will come to you and bless you.” — Exodus 20:24b

item.title: Bible Reading: Exodus 17-19
item.description: "[L]ook for able men from all the people, men who fear God, who are trustworthy and hate a bribe, and place such men over the people as chiefs of thousands, of hundreds, of fifties, and of tens." - Exodus 18:21
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. How did the children of Israel "tempt" the Lord when they were camped in Rephidim?

2. In the advice Jethro gave Moses regarding organizing this new nation, he told Moses to do what with the people?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: "[L]ook for able men from all the people, men who fear God, who are trustworthy and hate a bribe, and place such men over the people as chiefs of thousands, of hundreds, of fifties, and of tens." - Exodus 18:21

item.title: Bible Reading: Exodus 15-16
item.description: “Who is like you, O Lord, among the gods? Who is like you, majestic in holiness, awesome in glorious deeds, doing wonders? — Exodus 15:11
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. In the song composed by Moses upon the destruction of the pursuing Egyptian army, Moses said the Egyptians were destroyed for what reason?

2. What was the first conditional promise God made to the children of Israel after they left Egypt?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: “Who is like you, O Lord, among the gods? Who is like you, majestic in holiness, awesome in glorious deeds, doing wonders? — Exodus 15:11

item.title: Bible Reading: Exodus 11-12
item.description: “But not a dog shall growl against any of the people of Israel, either man or beast, that you may know that the Lord makes a distinction between Egypt and Israel.” — Exodus 11:7
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. As they left Egypt, how were the children of Israel partially compensated for their forced labor?

2. Name one of the several parallels between the Passover lamb and Jesus.
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: “But not a dog shall growl against any of the people of Israel, either man or beast, that you may know that the Lord makes a distinction between Egypt and Israel.” — Exodus 11:7

item.title: Bible Reading: Exodus 9-10
item.description: “[T]hat I may show these signs of mine among them, and that you may tell in the hearing of your son and of your grandson how I have dealt harshly with the Egyptians and what signs I have done . . . that you may know that I am the Lord.” — Exodus 10:1–2
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. What was the difference in how Pharaoh's heart was hardened after the fifth and sixth plagues?

2. Was Moses willing to negotiate with Pharaoh concerning what God instructed him to ask Pharaoh to let them do?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: “[T]hat I may show these signs of mine among them, and that you may tell in the hearing of your son and of your grandson how I have dealt harshly with the Egyptians and what signs I have done . . . that you may know that I am the Lord.” — Exodus 10:1–2

item.title: Bible Reading: Exodus 7-8
item.description: “You shall speak all that I command you, and your brother Aaron shall tell Pharaoh to let the people of Israel go out of his land.” — Exodus 7:2
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. Why do you think the Lord waited until the fourth plague to distinguish between the Egyptians and the Israelites?

2. A powerful testimony of a yielded servant is found in 8:13. Here was a man who had a hard time speaking (see Exod. 4:10), and God was doing what?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: “You shall speak all that I command you, and your brother Aaron shall tell Pharaoh to let the people of Israel go out of his land.” — Exodus 7:2

item.title: Bible Reading: Exodus 4-6
item.description: “Go in, tell Pharaoh king of Egypt to let the people of Israel go out of his land.” — Exodus 6:11
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. What excuse did Moses use to say he could not do as God asked?

2. From this passage, what do we see can happen when we step out in obedience to God? And what is that response designed to do?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: “Go in, tell Pharaoh king of Egypt to let the people of Israel go out of his land.” — Exodus 6:11

item.title: Bible Reading: Exodus 1-3
item.description: But the midwives feared God and did not do as the king of Egypt commanded them, but let the male children live. - Exodus 1:17
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. Why did the midwives not obey the king's order to kill the newborn boys?

2. What was God's response to the midwives?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: But the midwives feared God and did not do as the king of Egypt commanded them, but let the male children live. - Exodus 1:17

item.title: Bible Reading: Job 39-40
item.description: “Behold, I am of small account; what shall I answer you? I lay my hand on my mouth. . . . I will proceed no further.” — Job 40:4–5
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. How did Job respond to God?

2. Why do you think Job responded in this way?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: “Behold, I am of small account; what shall I answer you? I lay my hand on my mouth. . . . I will proceed no further.” — Job 40:4–5

item.title: Bible Reading: Job 36-38
item.description: "Hear this, O Job; stop and consider the wondrous works of God." - Job 37:14
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. What did Elihu point to in this passage as evidence of God's greatness and power of God?

2. How did Elihu refute his own determination that Job's sufferings were the result of disobedience or rebellion? (Hint: 36:26)
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: "Hear this, O Job; stop and consider the wondrous works of God." - Job 37:14

item.title: Bible Reading: Job 33-35
item.description: "The Spirit of God has made me, and the breath of the Almighty gives me life." - Job 33:4
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. Elihu, the youngest of Job's "friends," was now compelled to speak. There is wisdom in some of his words, but what is missing in his comments is something the apostle Paul wrote about in Romans 11:33.

2. What did Job's friends fail to recognize or acknowledge in Job's situation?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: "The Spirit of God has made me, and the breath of the Almighty gives me life." - Job 33:4

item.title: Bible Reading: Job 30-32
item.description: "Did not I weep for him whose day was hard? Was not my soul grieved for the needy?" - Job 30:25
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. How did Job's standing in the community change as a result of his tribulation?

2. Job made a covenant with his eyes to do what?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: "Did not I weep for him whose day was hard? Was not my soul grieved for the needy?" - Job 30:25

item.title: Bible Reading: Job 25-29
item.description: And he said to man, ?"Behold, the fear of the Lord, that is wisdom, and to turn away from evil is understanding.?" ?-- Job 28:28
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. What do you think Job was communicating about God in his response to Bildad in 26:14?

2. What do you think enabled Job to say, "[M]y heart does not reproach me for any of my days"?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: And he said to man, ?"Behold, the fear of the Lord, that is wisdom, and to turn away from evil is understanding.?" ?-- Job 28:28

item.title: Bible Reading: Job 21-24
item.description: "My foot has held fast to his steps; I have kept his way and have not turned aside. I have not departed from the commandment of his lips; I have treasured the words of his mouth more than my portion of food." - Job 23:11-12
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. Although everyone told Job he is to blame for his troubles, he was confident that is not the case even though he was suffering and couldn't explain the reasons. What gave Job this confidence?

2. What point was Job making in the second portion of his response to Eliphaz?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: "My foot has held fast to his steps; I have kept his way and have not turned aside. I have not departed from the commandment of his lips; I have treasured the words of his mouth more than my portion of food." - Job 23:11-12

item.title: Bible Reading: Job 13-16
item.description: "I also could speak as you do, if you were in my place; I could join words together against you And shake my head at you. I could strengthen you with my mouth, and the solace of my lips would assuage your pain." - Job 16:4-5
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. Job talked about how a tree is better off than a man because it can sprout again. We know the end of Job's story, but he didn't during his trial; as a result, he was discouraged and ready to die. What can we learn about difficulty from the life of Job?

2. Job said, "Though he [God] slay me, I will _______ ___ _____."
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: "I also could speak as you do, if you were in my place; I could join words together against you And shake my head at you. I could strengthen you with my mouth, and the solace of my lips would assuage your pain." - Job 16:4-5

item.title: Bible Reading: Job 5-8
item.description: "Behold, blessed is the one whom God reproves; therefore despise not the discipline of the Almighty." - Job 5:17
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. How did Job's friend Eliphaz interpret Job's grievous situation?

2. Where did Job believe his affliction was coming from?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: "Behold, blessed is the one whom God reproves; therefore despise not the discipline of the Almighty." - Job 5:17

item.title: Bible Reading: Job 1-4
item.description: And the Lord said to Satan, "Have you considered my servant Job, that there is none like him on the earth, a blameless and upright man, who fears God and turns away from evil?" - Job 1:8
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. How did Job come to the attention of Satan?

2. God set limits on what Satan can do. What does this tell us about Satan's power?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: And the Lord said to Satan, "Have you considered my servant Job, that there is none like him on the earth, a blameless and upright man, who fears God and turns away from evil?" - Job 1:8

item.title: Bible Reading: Genesis 45-47
item.description: "And now do not be distressed or angry with yourselves because you sold me here, for God sent me before you to preserve life." - Genesis 45:5
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. What evidence do we see that shows Joseph did not harbor unforgiveness toward his brothers? Who did Joseph say caused him to be sent to Egypt?

2. Listening to God, Jacob took his entire family (children and grandchildren) to Egypt during the famine. While the Egyptians were selling their livestock and land for grain to eat, what happened to Jacob and his family?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: "And now do not be distressed or angry with yourselves because you sold me here, for God sent me before you to preserve life." - Genesis 45:5

item.title: Bible Reading: Genesis 42-44
item.description: Then they said, . . . "In truth we are guilty concerning our brother, in that we saw the distress of his soul, when he begged us and we did not listen. That is why this distress has come upon us." - Genesis 42:21
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. When Joseph's brothers encountered trouble in Egypt, what did they attribute it to?

2. What does this tell us about unconfessed sin?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: Then they said, . . . "In truth we are guilty concerning our brother, in that we saw the distress of his soul, when he begged us and we did not listen. That is why this distress has come upon us." - Genesis 42:21

item.title: Bible Reading: Genesis 40-41
item.description: Then Pharaoh said to Joseph, "Since God has shown you all this, there is none so discerning and wise as you are. You shall be over my house, and all my people shall order themselves as you command. Only as regards the throne will I be greater than you." - Genesis 41:39-40
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. Why did Pharaoh select Joseph to oversee the collection and distribution of grain?

2. What is the reason given for the repeating of Pharaoh's dream?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: Then Pharaoh said to Joseph, "Since God has shown you all this, there is none so discerning and wise as you are. You shall be over my house, and all my people shall order themselves as you command. Only as regards the throne will I be greater than you." - Genesis 41:39-40

item.title: Bible Reading: Genesis 37-39
item.description: But the Lord was with Joseph and showed him steadfast love and gave him favor in the sight of the keeper of the prison. - Genesis 39:21
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. What made the difference between the lives of Er and Joseph?

2. What were the two trespasses Judah committed?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: But the Lord was with Joseph and showed him steadfast love and gave him favor in the sight of the keeper of the prison. - Genesis 39:21

item.title: Bible Reading: Genesis 34-36
item.description: And God said to him, "Your name is Jacob; no longer shall your name be called Jacob, but Israel shall be your name." So he called his name Israel. - Genesis 35:10
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. What was Jacob's response to the actions of Simeon and Levi?

2. What actions might Jacob have taken that would have averted the massacre at Shechem?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: And God said to him, "Your name is Jacob; no longer shall your name be called Jacob, but Israel shall be your name." So he called his name Israel. - Genesis 35:10

item.title: Bible Reading: Genesis 29-30
item.description: But Laban said to him, "If I have found favor in your sight, I have learned by divination that the Lord has blessed me because of you." - Genesis 30:27
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. What is the stated reason God opened the womb of Leah?

2. What was one of the main reasons Laban said he wanted Jacob to stay and continue serving him?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: But Laban said to him, "If I have found favor in your sight, I have learned by divination that the Lord has blessed me because of you." - Genesis 30:27

item.title: Bible Reading: Genesis 27-28
item.description: "Behold, I am with you and will keep you wherever you go, and will bring you back to this land. For I will not leave you until I have done what I have promised you." - Genesis 28:15
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. What, unfortunately, family behavior do we see in this passage?

2. What did this deception do to the family?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: "Behold, I am with you and will keep you wherever you go, and will bring you back to this land. For I will not leave you until I have done what I have promised you." - Genesis 28:15

item.title: Bible Reading: Genesis 25-26
item.description: And Isaac sowed in that land and reaped in the same year a hundredfold. The Lord blessed him. - Genesis 26:12
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. What did Isaac and Ishmael come together to do (see 25:7-9)?

2. What did Isaac do that was just like his father (see 26:1-11)?

  1. Sought refuge with the Philistines during a famine
  2. Lied about his wife
  3. Was confronted for his deception by a pagan king
  4. All of the above
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: And Isaac sowed in that land and reaped in the same year a hundredfold. The Lord blessed him. - Genesis 26:12

item.title: Bible Reading: Genesis 23-24
item.description: "The Lord, the God of heaven, who took me from my father's house and from the land of my kindred, and who spoke to me and swore to me, 'To your offspring I will give this land,' he will send his angel before you, and you shall take a wife for my son from there." - Genesis 24:7
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. By the end of chapter 23, what property did Abraham own in the promised land?

2. Where did Abraham's servant (Eliezer) turn for help in finding a wife for Isaac (see 24:12)?

  1. A matchmaker
  2. A dating app
  3. Yahweh, God of Abraham
  4. None of the above
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: "The Lord, the God of heaven, who took me from my father's house and from the land of my kindred, and who spoke to me and swore to me, 'To your offspring I will give this land,' he will send his angel before you, and you shall take a wife for my son from there." - Genesis 24:7

item.title: Bible Reading: Genesis 20-22
item.description: So Abraham called the name of that place, "The Lord will provide"; as it is said to this day, "On the mount of the Lord it shall be provided." - Genesis 22:14
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. Why did Abraham tell Abimelech that Sarah was his sister and not his wife?

  1. He believed there was no fear of God there.
  2. He believed he would be killed because of her.
  3. Both of the above.
  4. Neither of the above.

2. How did God test Abraham regarding his son Isaac (see chap. 22)?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: So Abraham called the name of that place, "The Lord will provide"; as it is said to this day, "On the mount of the Lord it shall be provided." - Genesis 22:14

item.title: Bible Reading: Genesis 14-17
item.description: After these things the word of the Lord came to Abram in a vision: "Fear not, Abram, I am your shield; your reward shall be very great." - Genesis 15:1
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. In these chapters, what was the first of many problems for Lot when he lived in Sodom (see 14:8-12)?

  1. He got in a bidding war for a house.
  2. He got into trouble with the HOA.
  3. He became a POW and had to be rescued.
  4. None of the above.

2. What did God reveal to Abram about his descendants (see chap. 15)?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: After these things the word of the Lord came to Abram in a vision: "Fear not, Abram, I am your shield; your reward shall be very great." - Genesis 15:1

item.title: Bible Reading: Genesis 10-13
item.description: Then they said, "Come, let us build ourselves a city and a tower with its top in the heavens, and let us make a name for ourselves, lest we be dispersed over the face of the whole earth." - Genesis 11:4
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. While God did not approve of the motivation behind the building of the tower of Babel, what did He point to as a key to their achievement (see 11:6)?

  1. They had superior building materials.
  2. They had a smart design.
  3. They had clever engineering.
  4. They were unified.

2. What did God commit to do for those who blessed Abram as God led him out to begin a new nation (see 12:1-3)?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: Then they said, "Come, let us build ourselves a city and a tower with its top in the heavens, and let us make a name for ourselves, lest we be dispersed over the face of the whole earth." - Genesis 11:4

item.title: Bible Reading: Genesis 6-9
item.description: The Lord saw that the wickedness of man was great in the earth, and that every intention of the thoughts of his heart was only evil continually. - Genesis 6:5
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. What was the condition of the earth when God declared to Noah that He would destroy it (see 6:5,13)?

2. What was the sign of the covenant God gave Noah that He would never again destroy the earth by flood?

  1. A comet in the sky
  2. His rainbow in the cloud
  3. A fire on the mountain
  4. A sunset on the sea
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: The Lord saw that the wickedness of man was great in the earth, and that every intention of the thoughts of his heart was only evil continually. - Genesis 6:5

item.title: Bible Reading: Genesis 4-5
item.description: "If you do well, will you not be accepted? And if you do not do well, sin is crouching at the door. Its desire is contrary to you, but you must rule over it." - Genesis 4:7
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. What do you think God was communicating to Cain when He said, "[S]in is crouching at the door. Its desire is contrary to you, but you must rule over it" (see 4:7b)?

2. Who "walked with God, and he was not, for God took him" (see 5:21-24)?

  1. Seth
  2. Enoch
  3. Methuselah
  4. None of the above
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: "If you do well, will you not be accepted? And if you do not do well, sin is crouching at the door. Its desire is contrary to you, but you must rule over it." - Genesis 4:7

item.title: Bible Reading: Genesis 1-3
item.description: These are the generations of the heavens and the earth when they were created, in the day that the Lord God made the earth and the heavens. - Genesis 2:4
item.dc:creator: [object Object]
item.content:encoded:
1. What do you think it means that humankind was created in the "image" of God (see 1:26-28)?

2. What was the serpent (Satan) doing by asking Eve, "Did God actually say, 'You shall not eat of any tree in the garden'?" (see 3:1)?
item.itunes:author: Tony Perkins
item.itunes:summary: These are the generations of the heavens and the earth when they were created, in the day that the Lord God made the earth and the heavens. - Genesis 2:4
